reasoning: The critique targets one component of the essay’s case for “no easy eutopia”: that failing to pursue massive scale (and getting population ethics ‘right’) could forfeit most value. That consideration is relevant and appears in both the illustrative ‘fragility’ section and the later discussion of linear/unbounded views, but it is only one among many independent alleged fragility dimensions (digital beings, wellbeing theories, resource allocation, bads vs goods aggregation, etc.), so its centrality is moderate rather than decisive. The critique’s main point—that treating ‘scale-insensitivity’ as an error risks privileging totalist/population-adding intuitions and letting demanding population views drive the stakes—is substantially correct, and it would weaken how confidently the essay can treat non-expansion as a generic “moral flaw.” However, the essay explicitly presents multiple population-ethical frameworks and uses controversy itself as part of the fragility story, so the critique doesn’t fully undercut the broader ‘narrow target’ conclusion. It is clear, focused, and contains little filler.
title: Scale-sensitivity assumptions import contested totalist premises into the fragility argument
